div.p: RB MSS M1, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

To proof. Bot. Names Checked. 23/1/09.
MS found with a specimen of Senecio garlandi (MEL 666710) and (MEL 666709).
MEL 666710 label in M's hand: 'Senecio macrodontus, A. Rich. var Garlandi. Wagga-Wagga 1891 J. K. Garland'. J. R. Garland?
MS notes with MEL 666710 in M's hand: ' Senecio macrodontus, Ach Rich var. Senecio Garlandi. Tall, somewhat shrubby; leaves sessile, mostly lanceolar-ovate, serrulated, with bilobed base elapsing, at the underside as well as the branches and peduncles whitish from a closely appressed lanuginous indument; headlets small, corymbously paniculate; involucre almost semi-ovate, supported by severalshortnarrow and pointed bracts; upper portion of the disk-flowers soon exserted; ray-flowers several comparatively ahort; achenes furrowed, sparsely beset with minute hairlets, the annular summit rather conspicuous. Near Wagga-Wagga; J. K. Garland. Leaves firmly chartaceous, occasionally to 7 inches long and to 3 inches broad. Involucre hardly above 1/6 inch long, consisting of about 12 bracts. Lignales broadish in proportion to their length. Achenes brownish, hardly 1/10 inch long. Probably only an extreme form of S. dryadens.' J. R. GARLAND

div.p: Since receipt of your last letter, I have not, until a few days ago had an opportunity of going out to the Hanging Rock for a further supply of the "Senecio." I now send you some specimens from various parts of the plant, including some ripe seeds in heads. — It is difficult to procure good sound heads with ripe seed as the heads are generally much injured by caterpillars.

The plant is a shrub or [...] shrub sometimes attaining a height of 5 or 6 feet, the flowering branches appear to die back after the seed ripens. All the plants which I have seen are growing amongst the rocks at the foot of the perpendicular face of the Hanging Rock Mountain & thus are sheltered from the Westerly winds. —
Wishing you the complements of the season
